授業の概要・背景:
Transnational Histories of Canada.  
The course will cover select topics, from concepts to specific case studies. This material will be explored via lectures/seminar discussion.
授業方法: A blend of short lecture, seminar discussion and presentation.

第1回:
Introduction to Transnational History and Canada

Defining transnational history: moving beyond the nation-state framework.

Key concepts: empire, diaspora, migration, borderlands, and Indigenous sovereignty.

The historical interconnectedness of the Americas, the Atlantic world, and global empires.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class.
第2回:
Indigenous Sovereignty in a Global Context: Networks, Resistance, and Adaptation Indigenous peoples’ worldviews and their transnational networks before European contact (trade, alliances, and knowledge exchange).

Indigenous resistance to colonization and participation in global struggles (e.g., the fur trade, alliances during colonial wars).

Indigenous-settler relations as transnational encounters.
Read suggested readings, reflect and prepare questions for next class. 2 hours.
第3回:
The Atlantic World: European Colonialism and the Fur Trade

The emergence of the Atlantic World: cross-cultural encounters and global trade networks (fur, sugar, slavery).

French and British colonial ventures in Canada and their connections to global empires. 

The role of Indigenous peoples in the Atlantic fur trade and European.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. 2 hours.
第4回:
Slavery, Abolition, and the Canadian Context
The history of slavery in Canada and its connections to transnational slavery systems.
The abolition movement in North America and the Caribbean.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. 2 hours.
第5回:
Migrant Movements and Diasporas
Immigration to Canada in the 19th and early 20th centuries
Transnational networks of migration and the impact of global economic conditions on Canadian settlement patterns.
Diasporas and the formation of ethnic communities: cultural exchange, assimilation, and resistance.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours.
第6回: Case Study: Komagata Maru (1914) and Japanese in British Columbia
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours.
第7回:
Imperialism, Confederation, and the Transnational State

The influence of British imperialism on the formation of the Canadian Confederation.

Canadian involvement in global imperial conflicts: the Boer War, and the First World War.

Relations between Canada, the United States, and Britain in the early 20th century.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours.
第8回:
Global Conflicts, National Identity: Canada’s Participation in the World Wars

Canada’s involvement in the First and Second World Wars: international alliances and the emergence of a separate Canadian identity.

The role of Canada in post-war decolonization and peacekeeping efforts.

Global shifts in power, the Cold War, and Canada’s changing role in international affairs
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours.
第9回:
Indigenous Sovereignty, Globalization, and Resistance

The impact of globalization on Indigenous communities in Canada: economic, environmental, and cultural shifts.

Indigenous sovereignty movements in Canada and their connections to global Indigenous rights frameworks.

Transnational Indigenous solidarity movements and the global struggle for environmental justice.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours
第10回:
Decolonization, Global Movements, and Canada’s Shifting Role. 

The development of Canada’s foreign policy in relation to former colonies and the United Nations.

The influence of global movements (civil rights, feminism, environmentalism) on Canadian society.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours.
第11回: Canada in the 21st Century: Transnational Networks, Globalization, and Sovereignty.
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours.
第12回: Case Study
Read suggested readings; reflect and prepare questions for next class. Think of choosing a topic for final reflection paper. 2 hours.
第13回: Class Project
Work on final reflection paper. 6 hours.
第14回: Class Project
Work on final reflection paper. 6 hours.

成績評価備考:
備考　Note
Class project: For the class project paper the students should write a report on the collaborative class project that reflects one of the substantive topics discussed in class, that is, a transnational aspect of Canadian history (e.g., Canada’s role in global peacekeeping, migration patterns, or Indigenous transnational resistance). The paper should be typed in MS Word, in ENGLISH. It should include a) the title page that contains the name of the student and the topic of the paper, and b) two or more pages of the reﬂection text itself. The paper does not have to be more than two pages.
